I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Asset and liability management (ALM) refers to the optimal and holistic management of 
the  balance  sheet  in  financial  institutions  and  industrial  companies,  with  the  objective  of 
managing and mitigating risks associated with interest rates, foreign exchange, and liquidity, 
among others. By analyzing and managing the different classes of assets and liabilities, ALM 
also minimizes the cost of capital and imposes an adequate transfer pricing mechanism within 
institutions.  It  ensures  an  entity’s  long-term  financial  health  through  forward-looking 
management of capital adequacy and financial ratios. An ALM committee (ALCO) structure 
provides the best practice governance model to promote sound financial management at the 
highest level of corporate management. 
 
2.  This technical assistance (TA)1 is a pilot initiative. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
will conduct ALM and risk management workshops for regional clients to help build awareness 
and strengthen financial management capacity. The workshops will facilitate participants to 
learn about long-term perspectives, contemporary issues related to financial risks, volatility in 
financial markets, and how to manage financial risks. The design and monitoring framework is 
attached as Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Financial institutions in ADB’s client countries have high exposures to interest rate-
sensitive securities and long-term liabilities with inadequate or non-existent ALM frameworks 
and  practices.  Financial  institutions  in  most  of  ADB’s  client  countries  regularly  take  large 
positions with significant interest rate and currency risks. These institutions also typically have 
large mismatches in assets and liabilities. 
 
4.  With a surge in private capital inflows (foreign direct investments, portfolio inflows, and 
bank debt), the financial markets are demanding more transparency in the management of 
financial institutions. As was amply demonstrated in 1997 and earlier financial crises, financial 
institutions in developing countries with inadequate or no ALM discipline have been ruthlessly 
punished by the financial markets, suffered severe losses, and experienced failures as a result 
of their exposure to changes in interest rates and exchange rates, asset defaults, and turbulent 
equity markets. In many cases, these risks were unnecessary and could easily have been 
avoided with effective ALM. Winning and retaining the confidence of financial markets have 
become major objectives of financial institutions. 
 
5.  Domestic financial institutions need better ALM and risk management discipline if they 
are to compete with new global players. Indeed, today, it is inconceivable for any major financial 
institution to ignore the international standards and norms such as Basel II. There is a need for 
much more attention to be paid to financial stability and risk management both at individual 
institutions  and  throughout  the  financial  system.  Basel  II  is  designed  to  improve  risk 
management at individual institutions by covering such issues as capital adequacy, liquidity 
management,  sensitivity  to  market  risk,  foreign  assets  and  liabilities,  domestic  assets  and 
liabilities, and credit risk management. 
 
6.  The ADB Treasury Department manages the assets and liabilities of ADB’s balance 
sheet according to best ALM principles. ADB regularly interacts with investors, rating agencies, 
major banks, regulators and peer multilaterals on financial policy and funding (including bond

issuance in domestic capital markets). In addition, the Treasury Department has conducted 
workshops  for  sovereign  clients  on  (i)  London  interbank  offered  rate-based  loan  products;  
(ii)  debt  management  products;  (iii)  currency  management;  (iv)  special  drawing  rights 
conversion  offers,  and  (v)  legacy  loan  conversion.  However,  to  date,  there  has  been  no 
extensive  regional  treatment  of  ALM  and  risk  management  issues  involving  nonsovereign 
clients from the financial sector. 
 
7.  ADB (represented by the Treasury Department) is a founding member of the multilateral 
development bank (MDB)-ALM Forum, which provides participants with a platform to (i) review 
and share their experience of ALM and risk management practices and policies, and (ii) resolve 
practical issues in implementing such policies. ADB actively participates in the annual MDB 
Forum, and hosted the 2005 forum in Manila.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The overall goal of this TA is to support participating institutions (mainly nonsovereign 
banking clients of ADB) to adopt international bank standards and best practices, including 
ALM  and  risk  management  policies,  for  critical  banking  operations.  The  TA  will  promote 
effective financial frameworks to manage financial risks and expand financial resources, and 
will encourage clients to enhance their financial policies, procedures and capabilities for the 
effective management of their assets and liabilities, including mitigation of financial risks in 
response to rapid expansion. 
 
9.  The TA will be an extension of the Treasury Department’s new loan products outreach 
program. As a pilot initiative, it will (i) enhance ADB’s capacity to deal with ALM and risk 
management issues, (ii) improve ADB’s understanding of the scope and types of assistance 
specific to ALM and risk management in Asia and the Pacific, and (iii) provide a platform for 
analyzing key ALM issues and trends, and type of financial instruments and tools used by the 
financial participants in managing their ALM risks. 
 
10.  The  TA  has  two  main  expected  outcomes.  First,  by  facilitating  and  promoting  the 
concept of ALM and ALCO decision-making, it will enable participating institutions to improve 
their financial management capacity and practices. Second, cross-border financial interaction on 
best practices and experiences in ALM will help participants to compete on equal terms and will 
support collaborative capacity building in the financial sector (pillar 3 of the regional cooperation 
and integration strategy).2 For example, the workshops will: 
 
(i)  facilitate  cross-learning  and  sharing  of  experiences  on  (a)  local  currency 
instruments, (b) ALM and risk management, (c) resource mobilization, (d) capital 
adequacy management, and (e) valuation of illiquid assets; and 
(ii)  share  ALM  issues  related  to  foreign  currency  exposure  using  financial 
instruments  (including  derivatives)  commonly  available  in  developed  financial 
markets.  
 
11.  Domestic commercial banks (including nonbank financial institutions and capital market 
participants) in many ADB developing member countries (DMCs) could provide long-term debt 
financing for certain projects (such as in providing long-term local currency financing at fixed

3
interest rate for infrastructure projects). However, prudent financial risk management and ALM 
practices have to be adopted before such forms of financing can be provided on a sustained 
basis. 
 
12.  Trade finance, swaps, and other transactions between international and domestic banks, 
and  among  domestic  banks,  require  the  establishment  of  “bank  limits”  based  on  credit 
assessments and ratings. By helping participating DMC banks and other financial institutions 
adopt ALM and risk management practices that are in line with international best standards, the 
TA will encourage these banks to prove that they deserve larger and longer-term bank limits, 
and give comfort to international banks that it is prudent to provide such limits especially during 
the current period of tightening liquidity and risk aversion. 
 
13.  Banking  institutions  can  manage  financial  risk  through  (i)  hedging  instruments,  
(ii) promoting the proper utilization of capital through transfer pricing, and (iii) using economic 
capital and risk sharing through securitization to best utilize capital. Financial institutions need to 
improve their creditworthiness and to put in place more transparent accounting, risk assessment 
and risk management practices before attracting national, regional and international investors.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will be implemented in consultation with the ADB Private Sector Operations 
Department, regional departments (governance and finance divisions), the Office of Regional  
Economic Integration, and the Risk Management Unit to (i) identify resource speakers and 
participants from various countries for the ALM and risk management forum; and (ii) achieve an 
appropriate mix of (a) smaller and less sophisticated banks (including local and/or domestic 
banks); (b) larger and more sophisticated banks; and (c) knowledgeable clients to share their 
experiences and expertise in areas of implementation and regulation.  
 
15.  Participants  and  topics  will  be  carefully  managed  so  the  TA  can  be  successfully 
implemented  within  a  limited  budget.  Workshops  may  be  grouped  by  focus  areas,  or  by 
participants. Each workshop will include participants across various DMCs to ensure that cross-
country benefits are achieved.  
 
16.  Resource speakers will be invited from regional regulators, rating agencies, medium-
sized  financial  institutions,  multilateral  development  banks,  financial  associations,  and  risk 
management associations. The international consultant and the responsible ADB member of 
staff will ensure that the agenda and materials are properly designed. The target audience from 
nonsovereign participants will include financial practitioners from financial institutions ADB either 
has worked with or may work with. Participants should be ALM or risk management practitioners 
with at least 3 years of working experience and should be fluent in written and spoken English. 
 
17.  Best practices and case studies will be disseminated through the ADB website. The TA 
may identify a potential sponsor or sponsors from the region who will champion ALM and risk 
management financial capacity building as a center of knowledge.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the Executing Agency. ADB, through the Treasury Department, will be 
responsible  for  the  overall  management  and  monitoring  of  the  TA  activities,  including 
supervising the work of the TA consultants. One international consultant will work on a retainer 
basis  for  a  total  of  up  to  6  person-months,  and  may  be  assisted  by  a  part-time  national 
consultant for up to 6 person-months. The consultants will be engaged by ADB as individual 
consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  The TA will: 
 
(i)  be implemented from September 2008 to December 2009; 
(ii)  include two or three workshops (at ADB headquarters and/or regional financial 
hubs) with 30 participants each; 
(iii)  produce a summary of issues raised to be shared among the participants; 
(iv)  post case studies on the ADB website and publish them in financial magazines; 
and  
(v)  use the ADB C-cube system to share information on ALM and risk management 
issues. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $320,000 on a grant basis 
for Supporting Regional Capacities for Financial Asset and Liability and Risk Management, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Asset  and  Liability  Management  (ALM)  and  Risk  Management  Specialist 
(international, up to 6 person-months on a retainer basis) 
 
1.  The specialist should have (i) solid experience in facilitating ALM and risk management 
discussions, including designing courses related to ALM and risk management applications;  
(ii) a good reputation and experience in similar assignments of coordinating events, conducting 
workshops,  and  writing  practical  case  studies  and  papers;  and  (iii)  strong  analytical  and 
communication skills. Under the supervision of a member of staff of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), the tasks of the consultant will include: 
 
(i)  facilitation of workshops and round table discussions for the pilot initiative on 
regional capacities on financial ALM and risk management; 
(ii)  design  of  agenda  and modules,  and  coordination  of  materials  with resource 
speakers keeping participants in mind; 
(iii)  development of a study report on ALM and risk management practices (including 
valuation and treatment of illiquid assets in the balance sheet) and ADB’s future 
involvement on such issues; 
(iv)  preparation of one to two case studies as per discussions in the workshops and 
articles for publications; 
(v)  guidance of ADB information technology staff in the preparation of C-cube; and 
(vi)  identification of potential sponsors from the region that will champion ALM and 
risk management financial capacity building as a center of knowledge, and laying 
out of specific cost and terms of reference for such initiative. 
 
B.  Training/Workshop Coordinator (national, up to 6 person-months on a retainer basis) 
 
2.  The  coordinator  should  have  (i)  substantial  experience  in  planning  and  managing 
workshops and conferences, and managing databases; and (ii) strong experience in organizing 
events  in  the  financial  sector,  especially  in  seeking  ideas  on  topics  of  interest,  resource 
speakers and in evaluating lists of participants. The coordinator will be in charge of all logistical 
and financial arrangements for the resource speakers and training participants, including travel, 
accommodation, venue, food and beverage, registration, and presentation materials. Under the 
supervision of the international consultant and ADB staff, the tasks of the coordinator will 
include: 
 
(i)  research and identification of resource speakers and discussion topics for the 
pilot initiative on regional capacities on financial ALM and risk management; 
(ii)  administrative and logistical support of training events particularly workshops; 
(iii)  assistance  in  the  selection  of  participants,  preparation  of  agenda,  and 
dissemination of information among the participants; 
(iv)  assistance in the preparation of case studies and C-cube; and 
(v)  performance of administrative and ad hoc support to the ADB member of staff 
and international consultant.
